statement.p: One measure of ductility, the ability of metal to be pulled into wires, is area reduction. This is measured as the percent decrease of area after pulling a sample piece of metal. The image above illustrates the metal sample before (on top) and after the pull (on bottom). A is the area of the round sample before the pull. B is the area after the pull (in this case pulled apart). The formula is \displaystyle{R}=\frac{{{A}-{B}}}{{A}}\times{100}.

Guido uses callipers to measure the diameters and calculates the areas \displaystyle{A}=\pi\frac{{\left({d}_{{A}}\right)}^{{2}}}{{4}} and \displaystyle{B}=\pi\frac{{\left({d}_{{B}}\right)}^{{2}}}{{4}}, where \displaystyle{d}_{{A}} and \displaystyle{d}_{{B}} are the diameters. He uses these to calculate the area reduction. Wolfgang calculates the area reduction using the same formula but solely the diameters (effectively \displaystyle{A}={d}_{{A}} and \displaystyle{B}={d}_{{B}}).
Do they end up with the same result for ductility?
